newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: TENNIS-HEALTHY SAMPRAS ISSUES WARNING TO RIVALS.
newsitem.headline: TENNIS-HEALTHY SAMPRAS ISSUES WARNING TO RIVALS.

text.p: A revitalised world number one Pete Sampras on Wednesday promised a stronger challenge to regain the Australian Open title after his shock early exit last year.

Sampras handed his rivals a warning in his first competitive match of the season with a 6-4 7-5 win against Germany's Michael Stich at the Colonial Classic in Melbourne, a warm-up exhibition event for the Open which starts on Monday.
But it was his state of health as much as his current form that gave the 25-year-old American reason for optimism.
Sampras, who lost to unseeded Australian Mark Philippoussis in a stunning third round upset in Melbourne in 1996, said he felt fresher mentally this year.
His preparation contrasts sharply to last year when Sampras said he went into the Open suffering the lingering effects of influenza.
"Philippoussis out-played me, but I didn't feel quite as fresh as I do this year. Last year I wasn't quite there," said the U.S. Open champion, who won his only Australian Open title three years ago.
"I was very tired and I came down here sick. But this year I've had a good break, I've got here ready and eager to go."
Meanwhile, defending Australian Open champion Boris Becker said he was still affected by a wrist injury that disrupted his season last year, including one enforced 10-week break.
"The wrist is not 100 percent but I have had worse so I can't complain," said Becker, the world number six, after beating Ukraine's Andrei Medvedev 7-6 (7-3) 6-1.
"Even a healthy body feels the effects of playing on new surfaces with new balls, and a beaten up one like mine is going to feel it even a bit more," said the 29-year-old German.
Compatriot Stich is also worried by a slight injury scare ahead of the Open after straining a left thigh muscle during the match against Sampras on the opening day of the Classic at Kooyong.

"The leg was not perfect and it hurt a bit on court," said Stich, the world number 19. "I felt it especially when I was trying to push off on the leg during my service. I don't think it is serious but we will find out next week," he said.
American Michael Chang, the defending champion at Kooyong and world number two, beat Sweden's Thomas Enqvist 7-5 6-4.
"Regardless of the situation -- whether is a grand slam, a regular tournament or an exibition like this -- I always try to win to get an edge on the other guy," Chang said.
In the final match of the day, French Open champion Yevgeny Kafelnikov of Russia beat American Jim Courier 7-6 (10-8) 6-4.
